Real Estate 721 provides an introduction to real estate with a focus on investment and financing issues. Project evaluation, financing strategies, investment decision-making and real estate capital markets are covered. No prior knowledge of the industry is required, but students are expected to rapidly acquire a working knowledge of real estate markets. Classes are conducted in a standard lecture format with discussion required. The course contains cases that help students evaluate the impact of more complex financing and capital markets tools used in real estate. 

Students for the most part found this course to be “useful” and “worthwhile.” Many students enjoyed the fact that the class was “very applicable to the real world” and “unbelievably helpful in terms of understanding real estate valuations, risks and financing.” Students complained about the textbook, which was very high level and “much more complex than class examples,” therefore it “did not prepare students for the exams.” 

Students praised Professor Sinai’s “structured, organized, and digestible way of delivering so much complicated information.” He was readily available to help students, and was very knowledgeable about the market.  Professor Sinai’s lectures were “engaging” and a “pleasure” to attend. Students reported that Sinai had “a great ability to keep the discussions in class flowing in a focused way.” 

Students found this class “challenging, but very beneficial” and “worthwhile, even for non-finance majors.” The cases assigned for reading outside of class were much more complex than class examples, and difficult for students without a real estate background to understand. FNCE 601 is a prerequisite for this course.
